question.title: Selenium 2: Open link in new tab and close tabs

node.contents: I thought of a solution using JavaScript. Maybe that's the easiest way?

node.contents: I did not found a solution. It seems that there is no way to do this, see also the accepted answer.

node.contents: Would you share this solution? I'm having the same problem.

astNode.text: Would you share this solution? I'm having the same problem.

node.contents: I want to be able to open a link in a new tab in Selenium 2. Also i want to close the tab when i am finished interacting with the page. How is this possible if I have a WebElement of an <a> tag?

astNode.text: I want to be able to open a link in a new tab in Selenium 2. Also i want to close the tab when i am finished interacting with the page. How is this possible if I have a WebElement of an <a> tag?

node.contents: I am using the Java API of Selenium 2 with the Firefox Driver, running on Firefox 4.

astNode.text: I am using the Java API of Selenium 2 with the Firefox Driver, running on Firefox 4.

node.contents: thanks, that's a great approach

astNode.text: thanks, that's a great approach

node.contents: Wish I could have helped w/ FF specifically but unfortunately we use Chrome as our primary test browser. However the same general technique should work for others w/ their respective key combos.

astNode.text: Wish I could have helped w/ FF specifically but unfortunately we use Chrome as our primary test browser. However the same general technique should work for others w/ their respective key combos.

node.contents: Took awhile (~2 weeks) for me to track down the right sequence of commands, but this is by far the easiest method I've found for a Win7/Chrome setup to open a link in a new tab AND switch to the new tab automatically.

astNode.text: Took awhile (~2 weeks) for me to track down the right sequence of commands, but this is by far the easiest method I've found for a Win7/Chrome setup to open a link in a new tab AND switch to the new tab automatically.

node.contents: WARNING! Make sure to always perform the keyUp actions. If you fail to perform keyUp your system will keep those keys pressed until a reboot or keyUp occurs.

astNode.text: WARNING! Make sure to always perform the keyUp actions. If you fail to perform keyUp your system will keep those keys pressed until a reboot or keyUp occurs.

node.contents: Windows 7/Chrome:

astNode.text: Windows 7/Chrome:

elements.contents: WebElement elem = driver.findElement(By.linkText("MyLinkText")); // Chrome key combos: // SHIFT + CTRL + click = Open in new tab (and switch to new tab) // SHIFT + CTRL + RETURN = Open in new tab (in background) Actions act = new Actions(driver); act.keyDown(Keys.LEFT_CONTROL).keyDown(Keys.LEFT_SHIFT).perform(); // Wrap in a try/catch during implementation to ensure you perform keyUp(s). elem.click(); act.keyUp(Keys.LEFT_CONTROL).keyDown(Keys.LEFT_SHIFT).perform();

comments.text: // Chrome key combos: // SHIFT + CTRL + click = Open in new tab (and switch to new tab) // SHIFT + CTRL + RETURN = Open in new tab (in background) Actions act = new Actions(driver); act.keyDown(Keys.LEFT_CONTROL).keyDown(Keys.LEFT_SHIFT).perform(); // Wrap in a try/catch during implementation to ensure you perform keyUp(s). elem.click(); act.keyUp(Keys.LEFT_CONTROL).keyDown(Keys.LEFT_SHIFT).perform();

node.contents: to use selenium at its best we at sol-logics combine it with java.awt.robot class. you can send keys that can close a browser window. try using

astNode.text: to use selenium at its best we at sol-logics combine it with java.awt.robot class. you can send keys that can close a browser window. try using

elements.contents: Robot robot = new Robot(); robot.keyPress(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robot.keyPress(KeyEvent.VK_W);

units.rawText: Robot robot = new Robot(); robotkeyPress(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robotkeyPress(KeyEvent.VK_W);

node.contents: as far as i understood, this method only allows handling of `windows`, not `tabs`

astNode.text: as far as i understood, this method only allows handling of `windows`, not `tabs`

node.contents: The way I figure out for selenium 2, work fine for Chrome and firefox, IE has security check issue:

astNode.text: The way I figure out for selenium 2, work fine for Chrome and firefox, IE has security check issue:

elements.contents: Set<String> winSet = webDriver.getWindowHandles(); List<String> winList = new ArrayList<String>(winSet); String newTab = winList.get(winList.size() - 1); webDriver.close(); // close the original tab webDriver.switchTo().window(newTab); // switch to new tab

comments.text: // close the original tab webDriver.switchTo().window(newTab); // switch to new tab

units.rawText: Set<String> winSet = webDriver.getWindowHandles(); List<String> winList = new ArrayList<String>(winSet); String newTab = winList.get(winList.size() - 1); webDriverclose(); // close the original tab webDriver.switchTo().window(newTab); // switch to new tab

node.contents: I was afraid that this would be the answer. Thank you.

astNode.text: I was afraid that this would be the answer. Thank you.

node.contents: At the moment, the Selenium WebDriver API doesn't have any way of handling tabs. The project would really need a consistent, cross-browser set of methods for managing tabs before I would expect to see an implementation in one of the language bindings like Java. Until then, your JavaScript solution may be the only way, and remember that your code would then be responsible for managing the lifetime of that tab.

astNode.text: At the moment, the Selenium WebDriver API doesn't have any way of handling tabs. The project would really need a consistent, cross-browser set of methods for managing tabs before I would expect to see an implementation in one of the language bindings like Java. Until then, your JavaScript solution may be the only way, and remember that your code would then be responsible for managing the lifetime of that tab.

node.contents: What I use is the Robor class.

astNode.text: What I use is the Robor class.

elements.contents: Robot robot = new Robot(); robot.keyPress(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robot.keyPress(KeyEvent.VK_W); robot.keyRelease(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robot.keyRelease(KeyEvent.VK_W);

units.rawText: Robot robot = new Robot(); robotkeyPress(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robotkeyPress(KeyEvent.VK_W); robotkeyRelease(KeyEvent.VK_CONTROL); robotkeyRelease(KeyEvent.VK_W);

node.contents: This makes the Robot rapidly press and release the CTRL + W keys to simulate a user interaction. If you only use keyPress event, this will close all the tabs and windows of the WebDriver.

astNode.text: This makes the Robot rapidly press and release the CTRL + W keys to simulate a user interaction. If you only use keyPress event, this will close all the tabs and windows of the WebDriver.

node.contents: Here is how i did it using Python.

astNode.text: Here is how i did it using Python.

node.contents: This solution is a bit dirty but it works if you want to close the tab.

astNode.text: This solution is a bit dirty but it works if you want to close the tab.

node.contents: Im mimicking the mac shortcut CMD + W to close a tab, if you are running windows you may have to implement a different key combination.

astNode.text: Im mimicking the mac shortcut CMD + W to close a tab, if you are running windows you may have to implement a different key combination.

elements.contents: import from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys from selenium.webdriver.common.action_chains import ActionChains from selenium import webdriver driver = webdriver.Firefox() driver.get("http://www.amazon.com/gp/search/ref=sr_in_-2_p_lbr_brands_browse-_2895?rh=n%3A172282%2Cn%3A!493964%2Cn%3A502394%2Cp_lbr_brands_browse-bin%3ALytro") action_chains = ActionChains(driver) action_chains.key_down(Keys.COMMAND + "w") action_chains.perform() action_chains.key_up(Keys.COMMAND + "w") driver.implicitly_wait(5)
